awd_titl_txt: FMitF: Track I: Retargetable, Verifiable, Optimizable Computer-Aided Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project applies and extends ideas from computer science formal methods to the design and fabrication of manufactured items.  Computer-aided manufacturing promises to have transformative impacts on society for many reasons, including unprecedented ability for customization and low-volume manufacturing as well as more efficient and flexible fabrication plans (e.g., as material availability changes).  But designers and engineers need more flexible tools that can optimize across both the design stage and the fabrication-planning stages, and be robust to changing constraints.  This proposal’s novelties are foundations and prototypes that enable such tools, in particular by designing interfaces that are essentially programming languages in the computer science sense and amenable to automated program analysis for correctness and optimization.  This proposal’s impacts include new languages and tools for computer-aided manufacturing as well as demonstrations that fabrication can be automatically retargeted to use different materials and/or processes.

This project advances the state-of-the-art in both formal methods and computational fabrication, centered around the critical use of embedded systems. For computational fabrication, the project is organized around a central vision: manufacturing is a form of compilation that translates abstract geometric designs to equivalent concrete physical fabrication plans.  By decomposing manufacturing software into compiler-like layers of abstraction, the research enables the construction of automated, reusable,cross-domain analyses, optimizations, and synthesis for fabrication.  For formal methods, manufacturing introduces new challenges. It requires mixing computational and geometric reasoning, including constraints like materials that can be neither duplicated nor created from nothing, and that physical objects obey gravity and cannot occupy the same space as another object.  Additional challenges include concurrency (multiple moving parts during fabrication) and numerical approximations as objects are moved in continuous space.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to harness the power of tools and concepts from software formal methods to improve computer-aided manufacturing, particularly in the generation and verification of manufacturing plans. By bridging the gap between design and fabrication, the project aims to create tools that enable efficient design optimization, fabrication verification, and adaptation to different manufacturing systems. These innovations address critical challenges in the field, such as ensuring safety, minimizing fabrication costs, and making advanced manufacturing accessible to a broader audience.

A key insight driving this work is the realization that both product designs and fabrication plans can be viewed as programs, allowing formal methods to play a pivotal role in verifying and optimizing these processes. Product design involves composing geometric operations, while fabrication plans are sequences of physical instructions. This perspective allows the transformation of a design into a fabrication plan to be treated as a form of compilation. By leveraging ideas from compiler construction, including abstractions, program rewrites, and solvers, the project introduces a systematic approach to verify product designs, optimize manufacturing processes, and guarantee correct physical outputs despite variability in fabrication.

A major accomplishment of this project has been the development of methods to simultaneously optimize both product designs and their associated fabrication plans. By treating designs and fabrication instructions as programs, we created tools that explore a wide range of possible solutions to identify the best combination of design and manufacturing steps. This co-optimization balances trade-offs such as material efficiency, precision, and production speed. For example, in carpentry, our tools can suggest adjustments to a furniture design to simplify fabrication while minimizing waste. This integrated approach empowers users to create efficient, high-quality products and demonstrates how computational tools can enhance traditional manufacturing processes.

Building on this foundation, we extended these ideas to other domains, including textiles, sheet metal fabrication, and reusable part design. Knitting offers a unique manufacturing platform due to its ability to create seamless, customizable, and highly intricate designs. We developed tools to generate patterns that create optical illusions by precisely manipulating texture and color. These tools allow designers to produce complex, eye-catching patterns that were previously impossible to achieve using traditional methods. Beyond knitting, we applied these ideas to sheet metal fabrication, introducing tools for designing stronger, more efficient components, and to reusable part design, enabling sustainable manufacturing practices by repurposing existing components.

This project has broad societal and educational implications. By developing tools that make manufacturing more efficient and accessible, the project lowers barriers for small-scale manufacturers and individual creators, democratizing access to advanced manufacturing techniques. It also supports sustainable practices by enabling more efficient use of materials and reducing waste. The project has had a significant impact on education, providing training and mentorship to graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups. Insights from the research have been incorporated into university courses, enabling students to explore the intersection of computational tools and physical production. By fostering innovation in manufacturing, this work contributes to a future where high-quality, custom products can be produced responsibly and efficiently.
